A cold west to southwest flow ahead of a slow moving upper level disturbance brought some general light snow which was enhanced by the lakes during the morning of the 30th; this activity remained in place through the day, amounting to 2 to 4 inches. A single intense streamer formed over Lake Ontario and extended across Oswego County much of the night before dissipating during the morning of the 31st as it moved south. It remained over one spot only a few hours as it was transitional, but was intense enough to drop over a foot of snow on western Oswego County. Specific reports included: 14 inches at Hannibal and 7 to 11 inches as Oswego.

The lake effect event began as an upslope situation, as wraparound moisture pinwheeled around a departing storm system with snows increasing during the afternoon of the 19th. The snows amounted to several inches during Thursday evening before evolving into more pure lake effect overnight and most of Friday. The activity was most pronounced off the open waters of Lake Ontario and settled south Friday night as winds veered. The activity wound down on Saturday as high pressure built into the region. Totals topped two feet over portions of Oswego county. Specific snowfall amounts included: 35 inches at Redfield; 29 inches at Lacona; 27 inches at West Monroe; 25 inches at Palermo; 24 inches at Fulton; 22 inches at Barnes Corners; and 18 inches at Fair Haven.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow totals in northern parts of county over a nearly two day period ranged from 12 to 16 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bitter cold arctic air flowing over the warmer waters of Lake Ontario set the stage for a round of heavy lake effect snow across the eastern Lake Ontario region and Tug Hill Plateau. Over a foot of snow fell across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow totals in southern parts of county ranged from 6 to 12 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bitter cold arctic air flowing over the warmer waters of Lake Ontario set the stage for a round of heavy lake effect snow across the eastern Lake Ontario region and Tug Hill Plateau. Over a foot of snow fell across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow totals in northern parts of county ranged from 6 to 10 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Bitter cold arctic air flowing over the warmer waters of Lake Ontario set the stage for a round of heavy lake effect snow across the eastern Lake Ontario region and Tug Hill Plateau. Over a foot of snow fell across the region.

The combination of cold air pouring across the relatively warm waters of the Great Lakes, in addition to orographic enhancement led to locally intense snow squalls across portions of northern Herkimer County, beginning Friday afternoon February 20th, and ending early Saturday morning February 21st.||Isolated snowfall amounts of up to 8 inches fell within the most persistent snow bands, which occurred near Old Forge.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands brought around 8 inches of snow to northern parts of the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a low pressure system strengthened off the East Coast, a cold northwesterly flow of air brought lake effect snow southeast of Lake Ontario. Snowfall totals ranged from 4 to 9 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands brought around 7 inches of snow to southern parts of the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a low pressure system strengthened off the East Coast, a cold northwesterly flow of air brought lake effect snow southeast of Lake Ontario. Snowfall totals ranged from 4 to 9 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands brought around 7 inches of snow to northern parts of the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a low pressure system strengthened off the East Coast, a cold northwesterly flow of air brought lake effect snow southeast of Lake Ontario. Snowfall totals ranged from 4 to 9 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands brought around 4 to 9 inches of snow to northern parts of the county. Slaterville Springs measured 8.3 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a low pressure system strengthened off the East Coast, a cold northwesterly flow of air brought lake effect snow southeast of Lake Ontario. Snowfall totals ranged from 4 to 9 inches.

Low pressure east of Lake Ontario moved to the New England Coast. Colder air behind the low resulted in a general snowfall of 4 to 6 inches across the Eastern Lake Ontario Region. A narrow band of lake enhanced snow set up over Oswego County producing a swath of nine inch snowfall reports.

Lake effect snows developed off Lakes Erie and Ontario in a well-aligned, cold, unstable west to southwest flow.  Strong winds not along allowed the snow bands to extend well inland, but produced significantly reduced visibilities in blowing and drifting snow. The Lake Erie snows produced significant accumulations well into the Rochester metro area. Off Lake Erie, the event began in a southwest across northern Erie and southern Niagara counties, and then settled south into southern Erie and Wyoming counties by mid morning Thursday (10th) after dropping 2 to 4 inches. A short wave then approached and lifted the band northward for several hours during the day across the metro Buffalo area and across Genesee and Monroe counties, then settled slowly south and stalled out for many hours during the evening 10th with very intense snowfall rates across the Buffalo south towns and Wyoming county. This band also dropped down across the lakeshore areas of Chautauqua county with intense rates with major implications on the NYS Thruway. The NYS thruway was closed between Dunkirk and the PA line with hundreds of motorists stranded. The activity dropped further south and set up across the southern tier counties for much of Friday (11th) before drier air advected in during the evening. The activity weakened and ended by midnight. Specific snowfall amounts included: Springville 27 inches; Perrysburg 24 inches; Colden and Arcade 23 inches; Warsaw 22 inches; East Aurora and Batavia 17 inches; West Seneca 13 inches; and Buffalo and Rochester 3 to 9 inches (from north to south).|Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario ensued, several hours later. The band initially set up in the Watertown area Thursday morning and slowly settled south later Thursday into early Friday (11th) with intense rates across southern Jefferson and central Lewis counties. The band then settled further into southern Lewis and Oswego counties later Friday as winds veered a bit further before weakening Saturday morning as the drier air advected in. Specific snowfall amounts included: Highmarket 40 inches; Port Leyden 37 inches; Lowville 30 inches; Redfield 28 inches; Copenhagen 21 inches; Carthage 15 inches; and Watertown 11 inches.

A favorable cold, unstable air flow over the relatively mild waters of Lake Ontario developed a nearly stationary fetch of lake effect snow bands from Lake Ontario into portions of northern New York during the morning of December 10th. Localized snow bands delivered 6 to 12 inches across portions of southeast St. Lawrence and southern Franklin counties in New York, including 12 inches in Wanakena, 10 inches in Star Lake, and Tupper Lake.

A strong westerly flow of cold air moved across the relatively warmer waters of Lake Ontario resulting in the development of bands of snow which extended across northern Herkimer County into Hamilton County. Disturbances in the upper levels of the atmosphere moved over the region and helped to produce very heavy snow with snowfall rates as high as 2 to 4 inches an hour which led to near whiteout conditions at times. ||The heaviest snow occurred along Route 28 from around Old Forge in Herkimer County to around Inlet in Hamilton County, where snowfall amounts of 12 to 15 inches were reported.

Lake effect snows developed off Lakes Erie and Ontario in a well-aligned, cold, unstable west to southwest flow.  Strong winds not along allowed the snow bands to extend well inland, but produced significantly reduced visibilities in blowing and drifting snow. The Lake Erie snows produced significant accumulations well into the Rochester metro area. Off Lake Erie, the event began in a southwest across northern Erie and southern Niagara counties, and then settled south into southern Erie and Wyoming counties by mid morning Thursday (10th) after dropping 2 to 4 inches. A short wave then approached and lifted the band northward for several hours during the day across the metro Buffalo area and across Genesee and Monroe counties, then settled slowly south and stalled out for many hours during the evening 10th with very intense snowfall rates across the Buffalo south towns and Wyoming county. This band also dropped down across the lakeshore areas of Chautauqua county with intense rates with major implications on the NYS Thruway. The NYS thruway was closed between Dunkirk and the PA line with hundreds of motorists stranded. The activity dropped further south and set up across the southern tier counties for much of Friday (11th) before drier air advected in during the evening. The activity weakened and ended by midnight. Specific snowfall amounts included: Springville 27 inches; Perrysburg 24 inches; Colden and Arcade 23 inches; Warsaw 22 inches; East Aurora and Batavia 17 inches; West Seneca 13 inches; and Buffalo and Rochester 3 to 9 inches (from north to south).|Off Lake Ontario, a similar scenario ensued, several hours later. The band initially set up in the Watertown area Thursday morning and slowly settled south later Thursday into early Friday (11th) with intense rates across southern Jefferson and central Lewis counties. The band then settled further into southern Lewis and Oswego counties later Friday as winds veered a bit further before weakening Saturday morning as the drier air advected in. Specific snowfall amounts included: Highmarket 40 inches; Port Leyden 37 inches; Lowville 30 inches; Redfield 28 inches; Copenhagen 21 inches; Carthage 15 inches; and Watertown 11 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall range from 8 to 17 inches with the highest amounts recorded near Boonville.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense lake effect snow band dropped south into the far northern part of Oneida County late Friday afternoon on the 11th, and continued until the early morning hours of the 12th. Storm total snowfall ranged from 8 to 17 inches.

The winter lake effect season's second storm was a marginal one and restricted mainly to snows off Lake Ontario. It began following a cold front as a westerly flow set off a band of fairly heavy lake snows by midday Wednesday (16th) across portions of northern Oswego and southern Lewis counties. The flow veered to northwest Wednesday evening and snow bands shifted south across Oswego county. A good streamer off Georgian Bay reached western Lake Ontario and was enhanced as it crossed the lake right across the Rochester metro area which received several inches of snow during the evening. Another lake snow band developed over eastern Lake Ontario and dropped several inches as it crossed western Oswego county on a north-northwest flow.   This event was relatively minor with few affects. It did drop several inches on greater Rochester but it was during the mid and late evening with minimal traffic impact. Heavier snows were restricted to a small area in western Oswego county. Specific snowfall amounts included: Scriba 15 inches; Minetto 13 inches; Palermo 10 inches; and Martville 8 inches. The Rochester metro are received between four and seven inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred from the morning of the 16th to the early evening hours. Snowfall accumulations ranged around 1 foot.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred from the morning of the 16th to the early evening hours. Snowfall accumulations ranged around 1 foot.

An upper level disturbance brought a general two to four inch snowfall to the entire region. As the storm departed, lake effect snow developed off Lakes Erie and Ontario in the colder, westerly flow. The event was a short lived one���mainly in a twelve- hour period from Monday (28th) morning through the pre-dawn hours of Tuesday.  The snows were very disruptive in the Buffalo area during the afternoon commute as whiteout conditions prevailed as 4 to 10 inches of snow falling in just a few hours.  Off Lake Erie, specific snowfall amounts included: Alden 11 inches; Glenwood 10 inches; West Seneca 9 inches; Orchard Park and Elma 8 inches; Dunkirk and Warsaw 7 inches; and Buffalo 3 to 9 inches (from north to south). Off Lake Ontario, specific snowfall amounts included: Copenhagen 14 inches; Beaver Falls 11 inches; Watertown and Lacona 10 inches; Black River 8 inches; and Scriba, Carthage and Palermo 7 inches.

A strong cold front crossed the region on New Year���s Day. A broad area of lake effect snows develop along the south shores of Lakes Erie and Ontario late on the first. Some narrow intense bands developed in this area and extended up to twenty miles inland. The activity continued through Saturday (3rd) and then strengthened in place Saturday Night as a large area of moisture spiraled around a massive coastal storm off New England.  A general burst of moderate to heavy snow accompanied this synoptic feature as it dropped south and southwest across the entire region during Sunday, then finally the lake effect weakened and retreated to near the lakes again Sunday night.  This event was unique in many ways, most notably in the large amounts of snow off Lake Ontario back across much of the Niagara frontier. A general one to two feet fell over two days, with up to 30 inches around Niagara Falls. Another area of very heavy snow focused on Wayne to Oswego County where two to three feet fell. The Rochester area caught a bit less, but still up to 18 inches near the Lake.  Off Lake Erie, two feet or more fell near Chautauqua Lake from Mayville to Jamestown. |Specific snowfall totals Off Lake Erie included:  Mayville 31���; Jamestown 28���; and Perrysburg 26���. Off Lake Ontario, the reports included: 42��� at Fulton; 38��� at Lacona; 36��� at Marion; 34��� at Scriba; 32��� at Hannibal; 31��� at Niagara Falls; 30��� at Pulaski; 26��� at North Tonawanda, Kent and Williamson; 24��� at Lockport; 22��� at Oswego; 19��� at North Amherst; 16��� at Perry; 14��� at Tonawanda; and 9��� to 18��� in Rochester (from north to south across the city).

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 6 and 12 inches of lake effect snow fell across parts of southern Oneida County. Durhamville picked up the highest amount in Oneida County with around 12 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent westerly flow of very cold air brought heavy lake effect snows to the lake effect snow belts of north central New York from January 2nd through January 3rd. Snowfall accumulations ranged from 6 to 20 inches. The highest accumulations occurred in northern Onondaga county where around 20 inches fell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to twenty inches of lake effect snow fell in Onondaga County from January 2nd through January 3rd. The highest snowfall report came in from Liverpool where 20.2 inches of snow was measured. Cicero reported 19.3 inches of snowfall.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent westerly flow of very cold air brought heavy lake effect snows to the lake effect snow belts of north central New York from January 2nd through January 3rd. Snowfall accumulations ranged from 6 to 20 inches. The highest accumulations occurred in northern Onondaga county where around 20 inches fell.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between 8 and 11 inches of lake effect snow fell across parts of northern Madison County. The highest amount for Madison county occurred in Cazenovia where 10.8 inches of snow was reported.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent westerly flow of very cold air brought heavy lake effect snows to the lake effect snow belts of north central New York from January 2nd through January 3rd. Snowfall accumulations ranged from 6 to 20 inches. The highest accumulations occurred in northern Onondaga county where around 20 inches fell.

Although this lake effect event produced ���marginal��� snowfall amounts, the snows were accompanied by winds gusting to 35 mph. The blowing snow resulted in significantly reduced visibilities that affected the morning and afternoon commute periods.  Lake snows first developed in a southwest flow ahead of an approaching cold front. Activity had just about ended before another area of general light snow moved across the Lower Lakes late Wednesday (27th) night followed by a sharper cold front. This snow was enhanced dramatically overnight into Thursday morning off Lake Erie on a southwest flow again. A more typical west northwest flow set up Thursday afternoon in the wake of the front with several strong but transitional bands with upstream connections dropping across the northern counties. |Specific snowfall totals off Lake Ontario for the event included: 18��� at Hooker; 14��� at Redfield; 11��� at Highmarket and Harrisville; 10��� at Theresa; and 8��� at Watertown.  Off Lake Erie, the reports included:  12��� in south Buffalo and Mayville, 11��� at Lancaster; 10��� at Alden, North Tonawanda, and the Buffalo International Airport.

Off Lake Erie, the reports included:  12��� in south Buffalo and Mayville, 11��� at Lancaster; 10��� at Alden, North Tonawanda, and the Buffalo International Airport.

Although this lake effect event produced ���marginal��� snowfall amounts, the snows were accompanied by winds gusting to 35 mph. The blowing snow resulted in significantly reduced visibilities that affected the morning and afternoon commute periods.  Lake snows first developed in a southwest flow ahead of an approaching cold front. A strong, cold upper atmospheric low across central Canada produced a nearly persistent west to southwest flow of cold, unstable air across relatively mild Lake Ontario waters during the afternoon of January 27th and continuing through midday on January 28th. This resulted in lake effect snow bands that traversed portions of St. Lawrence county, New York with widespread snowfall totals of 4 to 7 inches with localized snowfall up to 10 inches. Some snowfall reports include; 10 inches in Wanakena, 7 inches in Canton, 6 inches in Potsdam, Gouverneur and Hannawa Falls.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow fell across parts of Onondaga County. 7 inches of snow was reported in Syracuse.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from the eastern Great Lakes region to the Maritimes on the 28th. A cold westerly flow of air developed behind this system which kicked off lake effect snow over north central NY. The lake effect snow was heaviest in Onondaga County where up to 7 inches of snow fell.

A weak low passed across Ontario into Quebec well north of the Lakes, with a trailing west-east trough stalling out north of Lake Ontario. This set up a westerly flow across the Lake and conditions became favorable to induce a single lake plume which moved onshore across central Jefferson County by noon Sunday and held pretty much in place until mid evening when winds veered a bit, pushing the band into southern Jefferson and northern Lewis counties. The heaviest snow fell over the southern and central parts of Jefferson and northwestern Lewis counties where 8 to 16 inches fell. The Watertown area was hard hit with 10-12 inches.

This set up a westerly flow across the Lake and conditions became favorable to induce a single lake plume which moved onshore across central Jefferson County by noon Sunday and held pretty much in place until mid evening when winds veered a bit, pushing the band into southern Jefferson and northern Lewis counties. The heaviest snow fell over the southern and central parts of Jefferson and northwestern Lewis counties where 8 to 16 inches fell. The Watertown area was hard hit with 10-12 inches.

The first lake effect event of the 2010-2011 winter season began the day after Thanksgiving. Light snows off Lake Erie began around midday the 26th concentrated across the Buffalo-Batavia metro areas. As winds shifted more westerly the activity settled south over southern Erie and Wyoming counties. The lake snow then weakened before daybreak as it dropped south across the western southern tier of New York and dissipated by mid morning. Colden reported 8 inches and Attica 10 inches. East of Lake Ontario a similar scenario ensued with the activity beginning during the evening of the 26th. There were two rather intense bands across Jefferson and Lewis counties through about midnight. The bands then merged during the early morning hours of the 27th before settling south and dissipating during the morning.  Rodman reported 8 inches of snow and Barnes Corners reported 10 inches.

The second lake effect event of the winter season was one of the most intense and disruptive storms on record for the Buffalo area. It will be remembered not only for its intense and deep snowfalls, but for the incredibly tight snowfall gradient on the northern edge across the most densely populated region of metro Buffalo, attesting to its remarkable steady state, moving less than 3 miles during a 30 hour period. This allowed snowfall rates of 1-2 inches per hour to fall over the exact same area. The event evolved quickly as a major synoptic storm departed the area. Temperatures on the 1st started the day in the 50s but fell rapidly. A lake plume developed off Lake Erie by early afternoon on a southwest flow and intensified by 3 pm as it rolled into the Buffalo South Towns. The band then lifted north a bit during the early evening and remained pretty much locked in place for the next 30 hours or so. There was the typical thunder and lightning often seen during early season events. The wind fields finally weakened with increasing shear as a surface ridge built in by Friday morning the 3rd, disrupting and dissipating the band.|Snowfall amounts were incredible within the band. A general 30 to 40 inches fell in about a five mile strip which ran from Lackawanna and southeast Buffalo, east northeast across northern West Seneca, south Cheektowaga, Depew and Lancaster over to Alden. Amounts dropped off steadily to the south, with about a foot in Orchard Park and less further south. The real story was the northern gradient though. Amounts dropped from two feet to a dusting in just a 3 or 4 mile distance! This was evident along north-south roads like Transit and Harlem. For example, no measurable snow fell at Main and Harlem, but two feet at Walden and Harlem. The Buffalo Airport was right at the cutoff, with 2 inches at its northwest corner and a foot at its southeast corner! Further west, no snow fell in Buffalo at North Street; four inches at fell City Hall and a foot fell near HSBC arena. |This event had major impact, not only in the 300,000 or so people affected, but from a major backup and shut down of the NYS Thruway from Exit 52 to 54, with hundreds stranded for almost 24 hours. |Reported snow totals:  42��� Depew; 30��� Elma, Lancaster and West Seneca; 23��� Marilla; 17��� Darien; 16��� Wales; 14��� Akron; 11��� East Aurora and Warsaw; and Buffalo trace across North Buffalo to 39��� across the southeast corner of the city.|Activity off Lake Ontario, usually fairly similar to Erie, did not materialize nearly as well this time. There was a broad area of snow showers and heavier snow, but single banding never did develop. Shear was much greater and temperatures a bit milder and marginal. A narrow band of eight inch snowfall fell across areas where the snow persisted longest���just north of Watertown (Calcium) over to Harrisville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent lake effect snow bands brought heavy snow to much of the county. Over a four day period, snowfall amounts ranged from over one foot to around 20 inches.  Auburn measured 20.3 inches, Cayuga recorded 16 inches, and Locke measured 13.3 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent northwest flow of cold air across the relatively warm waters of Lake Ontario led to a long duration, major lake effect snowstorm across a large part of central New York and far northeast Pennsylvania. The snows began on Saturday the 4th and became heavy at times downwind of Lake Ontario from the 6th to the 8th, then tapered down by the 9th. Hardest hit was the Syracuse area where up to 58 inches of snow fell on the east side of the City. Most of the Syracuse area received between 38 and 55 inches of snow with the official snowfall at Syracuse International Airport between the 4th and 9th measured at 46.1 inches. This is the 4th highest four day snowfall on record at the Syracuse airport. Other locations in central New York downwind from Lake Ontario picked up between 1 and 2 feet of snow. At the Binghamton Regional Airport, 21.7 inches of snow fell, which was the biggest lake effect snowstorm on record.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent lake effect snow bands brought very heavy snow to much of the county. Over a five day period, snowfall amounts ranged from over 15 inches to over 50 inches of snow. Some amounts measured across the county included 50.6 inches in Fenner, 48.7 inches in Cazenovia, 35.2 inches in Morrisville, and 16.8 inches in Canastota.

The snows began on Saturday the 4th and became heavy at times downwind of Lake Ontario from the 6th to the 8th, then tapered down by the 9th. Most of the Syracuse area received between 38 and 55 inches of snow with the official snowfall at Syracuse International Airport between the 4th and 9th measured at 46.1 inches. This is the 4th highest four day snowfall on record at the Syracuse airport. Other locations in central New York downwind from Lake Ontario picked up between 1 and 2 feet of snow. At the Binghamton Regional Airport, 21.7 inches of snow fell, which was the biggest lake effect snowstorm on record.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Persistent lake effect snow bands brought heavy snow to much of the county. Over a four day period, snowfall amounts ranged from over one foot to around 20 inches.  Auburn measured 20.3 inches, Cayuga recorded 16 inches, and Locke measured 13.3 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent northwest flow of cold air across the relatively warm waters of Lake Ontario led to a long duration, major lake effect snowstorm across a large part of central New York and far northeast Pennsylvania. The snows began on Saturday the 4th and became heavy at times downwind of Lake Ontario from the 6th to the 8th, then tapered down by the 9th. Hardest hit was the Syracuse area where up to 58 inches of snow fell on the east side of the City. Most of the Syracuse area received between 38 and 55 inches of snow with the official snowfall at Syracuse International Airport between the 4th and 9th measured at 46.1 inches. This is the 4th highest four day snowfall on record at the Syracuse airport. Other locations in central New York downwind from Lake Ontario picked up between 1 and 2 feet of snow. At the Binghamton Regional Airport, 21.7 inches of snow fell, which was the biggest lake effect snowstorm on record.

A strong northwest flow of arctic air with plenty of lingering synoptic moisture from a low over Quebec produced long lasting lake effect snow squalls to the southeast of Lakes Erie and Ontario. Upstream influences from Georgian Bay and Lake Huron only intensified the activity. |The event began on Sunday 5th with strong bands off Lakes Huron and Ontario. The Ontario band worked across the Rochester area during the afternoon and then slowly settled south overnight, and combined with a Georgian Bay band to drop 4 to 8 inches on Buffalo's north suburbs on Monday 6th. This activity broke down later Monday but strong bands set up Monday night and continued through Wednesday night in an area from Rochester to Syracuse as winds backed for better fetch. There was also a persistent band over far northern Oswego County northeast into the western Tug Hill, with a major upslope component, aided by the western edge of the synoptic snowfall.|To the west, the story was a major and long lasting plume which originated off Lake Huron and extended across London and Lake Erie and then on down across central Chautauqua and southwest Cattaraugus counties into northwest Pennsylvania. This plume was very persistent and moved only a few miles in three days. Snowfall amounts under this band were prodigious, up to near 4 feet at Randolph. Two to four feet fell within the narrow band off Lake Ontario.|Specific snowfall reports off Lake Erie included: Randolph 47 inches; Cherry Hill 34 inches; Perrysburg 25 inches; Hinsdale 24 inches; and Franklinville 19 inches. Off Lake Ontario reported snow totals included: Lacona 51 inches; Newark 42 inches; Fulton and Marion 29 inches; Rochester 24 inches; and Phoenix 22 inches.

The fourth lake effect event of the winter season followed on the heels of storm which brought a cold rain to most of the area. The event was long lasting and featured three ���sub��� events. Most of the accumulation occurred during these three sub event periods, a north to northwest upslope flow from late Monday the 13th through Tuesday morning the 14th which brought six to ten inches from Monroe to Wayne county and over a foot to the Chautauqua ridge; a rare narrow but intense band from Georgian Bay which worked slowly across the Niagara frontier during afternoon of Tuesday 14th dropping 4 to 7 inches; and a broader west northwest flow off the east end of Lake Ontario on Wednesday night and Thursday morning the 15th-16th dropped over a foot of snow over Oswego county. Again, lighter activity continued outside of these periods but accumulating snow fell at least until Friday. The four-day totals topped two feet over much of Wayne and Oswego counties and over a foot back across Greater Rochester as well as over some higher elevations south of Buffalo.|Off Lake Erie, storm totals included: 22 inches at Perrysburg; 16 inches at Randolph; 14 inches at Hinsdale; and 12 inches at Boston and Buffalo.  Off Lake Ontario, reported totals included: 35 inches at Lacona; 30 inches at Fulton; 28 inches at Walworth; 25 inches at Pulaski; 23 inches at Marion and 18 inches at Rochester.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of lake effect snow off Lake Ontario brought heavy snow to parts of the county. Snowfall totals in the heaviest areas ranged from about 5 to 9 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm that was nearly stationary over the Canadian Maritimes led to a persistent northwesterly flow of very cold air across the relatively warm waters of Lake Ontario producing another round of heavy lake effect snow for the snow belts of central New York. Total snowfalls ranged from 1 to 2 feet, with up to 29 inches reported|in Camillus in Onondaga County.

The four-day totals topped two feet over much of Wayne and Oswego counties and over a foot back across Greater Rochester as well as over some higher elevations south of Buffalo.|Off Lake Erie, storm totals included: 22 inches at Perrysburg; 16 inches at Randolph; 14 inches at Hinsdale; and 12 inches at Boston and Buffalo.  Off Lake Ontario, reported totals included: 35 inches at Lacona; 30 inches at Fulton; 28 inches at Walworth; 25 inches at Pulaski; 23 inches at Marion and 18 inches at Rochester.

The fourth lake effect event of the winter season followed on the heels of storm which brought a cold rain to most of the area. The event was long lasting and featured three ���sub��� events. Again, lighter activity continued outside of these periods but accumulating snow fell at least until Friday. The four-day totals topped two feet over much of Wayne and Oswego counties and over a foot back across Greater Rochester as well as over some higher elevations south of Buffalo.|Off Lake Erie, storm totals included: 22 inches at Perrysburg; 16 inches at Randolph; 14 inches at Hinsdale; and 12 inches at Boston and Buffalo.  Off Lake Ontario, reported totals included: 35 inches at Lacona; 30 inches at Fulton; 28 inches at Walworth; 25 inches at Pulaski; 23 inches at Marion and 18 inches at Rochester.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of lake effect snow brought heavy snow to northern parts of the county. Totals ranged from 1 to 2 feet, especially across western areas.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent westerly flow downwind of Lake Ontario produced heavy lake effect snow over northern Oneida County in central New York. Total snowfall across far northwest Oneida County near Camden ranged from 1 to 2 feet.

Colder air moving over the relatively warmer waters of Lake Ontario resulted in lake effect snow bands which impacted southern Herkimer County Tuesday evening, January 4th, into Wednesday morning, January 5th. The lake effect snow bands shifted to the south of Herkimer County Wednesday morning. The highest snowfall report received was from Poland with 7.8 inches, with other reports ranging from 3 to 5 inches.

A westerly flow of increasingly cold air followed a cold frontal passage on Sunday the second. A decent lake plume formed Sunday evening and continued into Monday across Oswego County with several inches. This band lifted north later Monday and Monday night into the St. Lawrence Valley on Tuesday morning (4th) before settling south again later Tuesday. It became intense as it settled across Oswego County Tuesday night with up to a foot as it was aided by deepening synoptic moisture from a clipper passing to our north. The band weakened but redeveloped again on Wednesday with several inches across Oswego County. Wind shear and a lowering inversion finally shut down the activity overnight Wednesday night. Specific storm totals included: 28��� at Fulton; 27��� at Minetto; 22��� at Scriba; 19��� at Palermo; 14��� at Oswego; and 12��� at Martville and Fair Haven.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve-hour snowfall totals ranged from 8 to 10 inches across the northern and central portion of Oneida County.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent westerly flow of cold air across Lake Ontario produced bands of heavy lake effect snow. Twelve-hour snowfall totals ranged from 8 to 10 inches across the northern and central portion of Oneida County.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 8 to 12 inches across the area.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system sitting over eastern Canada brought persistent northwest flow to central New York. Cold air crossing Lake Ontario brought heavy lake effect snow to the snow-belt areas. Snowfall totals ranged from 8 to 12 inches across Madison, Chenango and Delaware County.

This lake effect storm evolved gradually from a synoptic snow as a clipper exited to a northwest flow across Lake Ontario. A strong lake effect plume, enhanced by strong upslope flow, developed Saturday evening (the 15th) off Lake Ontario and focused on the Tug Hill of Lewis County and extended across northern Oswego and southern Jefferson counties. Six to ten inches fell in this area by early Sunday. A narrow, intense band developed Sunday morning and lingered most of the day���focusing on northern Cayuga and southern Oswego counties. The activity broke down Sunday evening and lifted out across the lake as winds became light and variable. Storm totals included: 22��� at Fulton; 12��� at West Leyden and Constableville; 11��� at Phoenix and Martville; 10��� at Minetto and Redfield; and 9��� at Barnes Corners.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals across the northern part of the county ranged from 5 to 11 inches. Point Rock measured 10.5 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Persistent northwest flow accompanied by a trough of low pressure brought significant lake effect snow to upstate New York. Three hour snowfall amounts of nearly 7 inches were recorded in Cazenovia during this storm. Snowfall totals ranged from 7.7 inches in Clay in Onondaga County to 10.5 inches at Point Rock in northern Oneida County. Snowfall totals of 7 to 10 inches were common across northern Onondaga, northern Madison, and central and northern Oneida.

This lake effect storm evolved from a departing synoptic system which gave most of western and central New York several inches of snow overnight on the 20th-21st. A brisk westerly flow followed with bands of lake snow setting up during Friday afternoon (21st) and continuing into the evening before dissipating after midnight as a ridge moved in. Off Lake Ontario, the heaviest snows fell over Oswego County where the activity was focused.  Specific storm totals off Lake Ontario included: 17��� at Minetto; 12��� at Palermo and Fulton; 10��� at Scriba; and 8��� at Martville and Harrisville. Off Lake Erie storm totals included: 13��� at Colden; 11��� at Springville and 7��� at East Aurora and Forestville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snowfall totals of 6 to 10 inches fell north of the New York Thruway corridor. Durhamville measured 10.6 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure over the Canadian Maritimes provided persistent northwesterly flow to Upstate New York during the period. Cold air flowing across Lake Ontario resulted in lake effect snow across the snow-belts of Oneida county. Lake effect snowfall totals of 7 inches fell north of the New York Thruway corridor.

On February 9th, a weak surface trough along with a broad west-southwest, cold cyclonic lower atmospheric flow across Lake Ontario accounted for a single lake effect snow band from Lake Ontario into portions of extreme southern St. Lawrence county.||Snowfall totals were 2 to 6 inches in southern St. Lawrence county with localized reports of a foot at Gouverneur.

This lake effect storm, as typical for late season, was restricted to Lake Ontario. Westerly winds began to produce lake effect snowbands during the early morning hours of the 9th across Oswego County. The winds backed ahead of a short wave trough during the day Wednesday and activity consolidated into a single, intense plume across north central Jefferson County just north of Watertown during the afternoon. The winds veered with the passage of the trough and the band consolidated over northern Oswego and west central Lewis counties. It was very intense in the evening through the early hours of Thursday the 10th. The activity drifted south and weakened with increasing shear. Specific snowfall amounts reported included: 25 inches in Pulaski; 24 inches in Redfield and Lacona; 22 inches in Scriba; 20 inches in Theresa; 15 inches in Barnes Corners and 10 inches in Copenhagen.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lake effect band of mixed rain and snow developed early afternoon November 17, and changed to snow while becoming heavy at times beginning around 4 pm.  The band persisted into the predawn hours of November 18, before shifting south of the area by 4 am.  Event totals ranged from 6 to 12 inches, with highest amounts of 12.9 inches near Point Rock and 12.5 inches near Stokes Corner.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the wake of a low pressure system that passed through November 17th, cold air poured over the region and a period of heavy lake effect snow developed downwind of Lake Ontario lasting into early November 18th.

Colder air filtered into the region over the relatively warmer waters of Lake Ontario resulting in lake effect snows in the Mohawk Valley. Snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to around 9 inches within the more persistent snow bands.

The 2011-2012 lake effect snow season opened with this marginal event. Snowfall totals were not exceptional, however, as often happens with the first storm of the season, it did cause several traffic over portions of Oswego County off Lake Ontario. Wind gusts in excess of 40 mph were observed at Oswego Coast Guard on Lake Ontario.  The snow began during the afternoon of the 17th with a brief period of lightning and thunder.  The heaviest snowfall totals were located across western Oswego County near Fulton where 12.5 inches was reported.  The upper ridge built quickly across Lake Ontario ending the lake effect snow Friday afternoon.

A cold front crossed the region and ushered in arctic air across the Great Lakes. Lake effect snow developed Friday Night (9th) with a loosely organized band across the St. Lawrence River. The band slowly consolidated into a better organized band over the Tug Hill by midday Saturday (10th). The band continued into Saturday evening eventually weakening and ending by Sunday. The highest snow amounts were focused over the Tug Hill with several readings nearing a foot including 10 inches at Lacona in Oswego County and 11 inches at North Osceola in Lewis County.

An area of low pressure tracked across the region and in its wake arctic air poured across the Great Lakes.  Off Lake Ontario, the long fetch of a westerly wind produced broad bands of lake effect snow over the upslope regions of the Tug Hill. Snowfall totals included 17 inches in Lacona and 15 inches in Redfield, both in Oswego County, and 9 inches at Constableville in Lewis County.

Off Lake Ontario, the long fetch of a westerly wind produced broad bands of lake effect snow over the upslope regions of the Tug Hill. A strong cold front moved across the region on New Year���s Day ushering in much colder air. Off Lake Erie, lake effect snow initially developed on westerly winds across the higher terrain of Southern Erie, Wyoming, Chautauqua, and Cattaraugus counties well south of Buffalo during the wee hours of the morning on January 2nd. Lake effect snow remained in place across the higher terrain of the Southern Tier through the 2nd. Winds turned northwest the night of the 2nd through the 3rd shifting weaker multiple bands further south. Storm totals included: 17 inches at Sherman, 16 inches at Cattaraugus, 13 inches in Jamestown, 12 inches at West Valley and Randolph, and 9 inches at Warsaw. Off Lake Ontario a band of heavy lake effect snow developed early on the morning of the 2nd across the Tug Hill Plateau. This dropped a foot of snow in about 10 hours before moving south across Oswego County and weakening along the south shore of Lake Ontario. Multiple bands of lake effect snow developed on northwest winds the night of the 2nd and into the 3rd but never gained much intensity, except across western Oswego County where moderate snow fell much of the day on the 3rd. Storm totals included 12 inches at Montague and Osceola and 9 inches at Bennetts Bridge and Fulton.

A strong low pressure system that moved over eastern Canada brought cold air across the relatively warmer waters of Lake Ontario, producing lake effect snows across the western Adirondacks. A foot of snow was reported in Inlet (Hamilton County) and 10 inches in Beaver River (Herkimer County).

Cold air crossing the relatively warmer waters of Lakes Erie and Ontario produced bands of lake effect snow. By Friday evening the 13th, a band of lake effect snow off Lake Erie developed along and south of Route 20 dropping snow at rates up to 2 inches per hour. These bands of snow remained nearly stationary to start and with winds gusting to 40 mph. The bulk of the lake snow fell overnight Friday night, centered off Lake Erie over the Chautauqua Ridge where a combined one to two feet of snow fell along the Chautauqua Ridge by daybreak. Inland up to a foot of fresh snow fell over central Wyoming County southeastward towards the western southern tier.  Specific reports received included: 34 at Perrysburg, 21 at Forestville, 16 at Glenwood, 15 at Warsaw, and 11 at S. Dayton.  Off Lake Ontario lake effect snow waited until the overnight hours as the cold air continued to deepen. Snowfall rates up to 2 inches were experienced across the Tug Hill region overnight as well. Snow totals neared a foot and a half on the Tug Hill region by Saturday morning. By daybreak weak bands of snow settled southward over areas southeast of Lake Ontario. Specific snowfall reports included: 18 at Redfield, Copenhagen and Montague, 15 at Fulton, and 10 at Theresa.

Cold air crossing the relatively warmer waters of Lakes Erie and Ontario produced bands of lake effect snow. By Friday evening the 13th, a band of lake effect snow off Lake Erie developed along and south of Route 20 dropping snow at rates up to 2 inches per hour. These bands of snow remained nearly stationary to start and with winds gusting to 40 mph. The bulk of the lake snow fell overnight Friday night, centered off Lake Erie over the Chautauqua Ridge where a combined one to two feet of snow fell along the Chautauqua Ridge by daybreak. Inland up to a foot of fresh snow fell over central Wyoming County southeastward towards the western southern tier.  Specific reports received included: 34 at Perrysburg, 21 at Forestville, 16 at Glenwood, 15 at Warsaw, and 11 at S. Dayton.  Off Lake Ontario lake effect snow waited until the overnight hours as the cold air continued to deepen. Snowfall rates up to 2 inches were experienced across the Tug Hill region overnight as well. Snow totals neared a foot and a half on the Tug Hill region by Saturday morning. By daybreak weak bands of snow settled southward over areas southeast of Lake Ontario. Specific snowfall reports included: 18 at Redfield, Copenhagen and Montague, 15 at Fulton, and 10 at Theresa.

Following a cold front that brought four to six inches of snow to the eastern Lake Ontario region, a broad west to east flow followed over Lake Ontario early on the 30th. A convergence boundary combined with little wind shear aloft, ample moisture in the boundary layer and cold air to provide ideal lake effect conditions. These ingredients combined allowed for a steady band of heavy lake effect snow southeast of Lake Ontario. Prior to sunrise on the 30th several inches of snow had fallen across far northwestern Wayne, northern Cayuga and western Oswego county. As the intensity of the snow band increased through the morning hours, the band of snow remained over western Oswego county with snowfall rates between three and four inches per hour over a several hour period.  The focus point for this lake effect snow was on the city of Fulton and vicinity where nearly three feet of snow fell. Snowplows at one point within the city had to stop plowing as visibilities within the heavy snow became dangerously low for driving snowplows. Winds gradually backed to westerly through the day, and by time the band of snow shifted northward it was rapidly weakening, making this event localized to primarily western Oswego county and vicinity.

While this event proved to have minimal impact on the Rochester metropolitan area because it occurred over a weekend, it was the first significant lake effect snowstorm of a foot or more for the major urban area in several years. A closed low situated over the southern half of Quebec brought cold, northwest winds to the region. Lake effect snow developed off Georgian Bay which consolidated into a single plume that extended southeast to the western third of Lake Ontario. The band of lake effect snow gathered additional moisture off Lake Ontario as it curved more to the east across Monroe County. Moderate to heavy lake effect snow then fell across a large portion of Monroe County during the early morning hours of Sunday, February 12, with accumulations of a foot or more experienced by daybreak. An arctic front sagged south disrupting the single lake effect snow band. Multiple bands of moderate lake snow oscillated across Wayne, Northern Cayuga and Oswego County from late Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Specific reported snowfall totals included: 12 inches at Rochester and Greece, 9 inches at Fulton and 8 inches at Newark, Walworth and Sterling.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Localized heavy lake effect snow occurred off of Lake Ontario and the Finger Lakes, resulting 5 to 9 inches of snow for portions of Cortland County.  This includes 8.7 inches in Homer and 8.0 inches in Cortland.  Most of this snow occurred in the morning to early afternoon hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spilled across Lake Ontario and the Finger Lakes from the north-northwest, resulting in localized heavy bands of lake effect snow for portions of Cortland and Southern Cayuga Counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Localized heavy lake effect snow occurred off of Lake Ontario and Cayuga Lake, resulting in a widely ranging 4 to 11 inches of snow in Southern Cayuga County.  This includes 11.0 inches 3 miles southeast of Dresserville, and 7.8 inches in Summer Hill.  Most of the snow fell in the morning to early afternoon hours.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spilled across Lake Ontario and the Finger Lakes from the north-northwest, resulting in localized heavy bands of lake effect snow for portions of Cortland and Southern Cayuga Counties.

A strong cold front crossed the region on Friday the 24th with strong winds that was followed by a colder northwest wind across the central and eastern Great Lakes. Lake effect snow started Friday evening off Lake Erie. Bands of snow forming Georgian Bay and Lake Huron proved to be beneficial in adding to the snow totals across Western New York, and the Genesee Valley through the day on Saturday. Specific reported snowfall totals included: 18 inches at Warsaw; 11 inches at West Valley; and 8 inches at Colden.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A main heavier band of lake effect snow developed across Northern Oneida County late morning through afternoon, and lasted into the evening of November 25.  The band shifted farther north for a period mid to late evening, then passed back southward to again hit Northern Oneida County from Midnight to 6:30 a.m. on November 26 before ending. Snow totals widely ranged from 4 to 11 inches.  The highest amounts were along the Tug Hill Plateau in the far northern reaches of the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A main heavier band of lake effect snow developed across Northern Oneida County during the late morning of November 25.  The band shifted back-and-forth through that afternoon into the night, before ending by 6:30 a.m. on November 26. Snow totals widely ranged from 4 to 11 inches.

Lake effect snows developed off Lake Ontario as a large upper trough crossed the Great Lakes Region.   Lake snows began to develop over Wayne and Oswego counties on Sunday the 25th in a northwest flow.  A westward shift in the winds lifted the snow band north across the Tug Hill region during the late afternoon and evening hours. The longer fetch fed the snow band with snowfall rates of one to two inches per hour. Snowfall totals exceeded one foot over the higher elevations of the Tug Hill plateau. Route 81 through Oswego County was closed temporarily Sunday disrupting Thanksgiving holiday traffic heading home. Specific snowfall reports received included:  Redfield 15 inches, West Leyden 13 inches, Lacona 12 inches, Sandy Creek and Pulaski 10 inches, and Constableville 8 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of lake effect snow dropped 6 to 8 inches across portions of northern Oneida county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A westerly flow of cold air across the relatively warm waters of Lake Ontario produced a band of heavy lake effect snow for portions of northern Oneida county from the late evening on the 28th until the morning of the 29th. Total accumulations were around 7 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow produced 9 to 14 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure tracked from eastern Michigan on Friday the 21st to southern Quebec on Saturday the 22nd. A cold northwest flow behind this system generated lake effect snow for a large part of central New York. Snowfall amounts ranged from 7 to 14 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow produced around 8 inches.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front swept from north to south on Sunday, leading to cold northwest flow over the Great Lakes. This generated lake effect snow for central New York. Snowfall amounts ranged from 7 to 13 inches for cities along and north of the New York Thruway.

After an area of low pressure crossed the Upper Great Lakes, lake effect snows developed off Lake Ontario under a cold, northwest flow. A band of snow developed over the southeast segment of the lake producing heavy snow across parts of Wayne, Northern Cayuga and Oswego counties Sunday evening through the early overnight hours. The band drifted north over Lake Ontario and weakened Monday Morning (21st). Snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour occurred. Specific snowfall amounts included:  18 inches as Fair Haven and Fulton, 15 inches as Palermo and Phoenix and 8 inches at Wolcott.

Lake snows persisted as a deep trough of low pressure became entrenched across the northeast United States. |Off Lake Erie, a band of lake effect snow developed along the Lake Erie shoreline Monday (21st) producing very heavy snow and difficult travel along the New York State Thruway corridor from Hamburg to the Pennsylvania State Line. Snowfall rates during this time reached about two inches per hour. From Tuesday through Thursday, multiple bands of somewhat lighter lake effect snow continued across much of the Southern Tier and occasionally drifted into southern Erie and Wyoming counties. The greatest totals off Lake Erie were found in southwest Chautauqua County and along the Chautauqua ridge where snow totals were near two feet. Specific snowfall reports included:  25 inches at Perrysburg and Ripley, 21 inches at Forestville, 18 inches at Glenwood, 16 inches at West Valley, 13 inches at Warsaw and 12 inches at Collins.|Off Lake Ontario, an intense band of lake effect snow developed east of the lake late Monday Night across the Tug Hill region and drifted slowly south across Oswego County on Tuesday producing more heavy snow along the way. Snowfall rates reached three to five inches per hour during this time. The band then settled along the south shore of the lake Tuesday Night with heavy snow along the entire south shore. Periodic bands of somewhat weaker lake effect snow then continued along the south shore of the lake through midweek. The greatest totals off Lake Ontario were found over Oswego County ��� nearing two feet. About a foot fell along much of the south shore within a few miles of the lake from Eastern Niagara County to Wayne County.  Specific snowfall reports included:  22 inches at Palermo and Phoenix, 20 inches at Fulton, 18 inches at Fair Haven, 15 inches at Osceola, 13 inches at Lyndonville, 12 inches at Sodus, 11 inches at Hamlin Beach, 10 inches at Newfane.

Specific snowfall reports included:  22 inches at Palermo and Phoenix, 20 inches at Fulton, 18 inches at Fair Haven, 15 inches at Osceola, 13 inches at Lyndonville, 12 inches at Sodus, 11 inches at Hamlin Beach, 10 inches at Newfane.

Lake snows persisted as a deep trough of low pressure became entrenched across the northeast United States. |Off Lake Erie, a band of lake effect snow developed along the Lake Erie shoreline Monday (21st) producing very heavy snow and difficult travel along the New York State Thruway corridor from Hamburg to the Pennsylvania State Line. Snowfall rates during this time reached about two inches per hour. From Tuesday through Thursday, multiple bands of somewhat lighter lake effect snow continued across much of the Southern Tier and occasionally drifted into southern Erie and Wyoming counties. The greatest totals off Lake Erie were found in southwest Chautauqua County and along the Chautauqua ridge where snow totals were near two feet. Specific snowfall reports included:  25 inches at Perrysburg and Ripley, 21 inches at Forestville, 18 inches at Glenwood, 16 inches at West Valley, 13 inches at Warsaw and 12 inches at Collins.|Off Lake Ontario, an intense band of lake effect snow developed east of the lake late Monday Night across the Tug Hill region and drifted slowly south across Oswego County on Tuesday producing more heavy snow along the way. Snowfall rates reached three to five inches per hour during this time. The band then settled along the south shore of the lake Tuesday Night with heavy snow along the entire south shore. Periodic bands of somewhat weaker lake effect snow then continued along the south shore of the lake through midweek. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow produced 8 inches of snow in Rome.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A westerly flow of cold air over the Great Lakes produced significant lake effect snow over Oneida county in central New York. Snowfall amounts ranged from 7 to 18 inches.

A rapidly deepening storm system moved eastward from Lake Huron and tracked north of Lake Ontario to southwestern Quebec. The system was followed by a westerly flow of very cold air across the still unfrozen Great Lakes which triggered lake effect snows downwind of Lake Ontario. Off Lake Ontario, lake snows organized into a narrow but intense band of snow over southern Jefferson and Lewis Counties as winds aligned down the long axis of the lake. This band sagged south across with snowfall rates of up to 2 inches per hour were observed. The greatest snow totals off Lake Ontario fell during two periods. During the first, six to as much as twenty-one inches were measured in central Oswego and southern Lewis Counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow produced 9 to 14 inches. The highest snowfall total of 14 inches occurred in Boonville.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold westerly flow produced significant lake effect snowfall in northern Oneida county in central New York.

A rapidly deepening storm system moved eastward from Lake Huron and tracked north of Lake Ontario to southwestern Quebec. The system was followed by a westerly flow of very cold air across the still unfrozen Great Lakes which triggered lake effect snows downwind of both lakes.|Off Lake Erie, a narrow but intense band of lake effect snow across Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties. Winds then backed to west-southwest and the band lifted north bringing lake snows into southern Erie and Wyoming Counties. As an upper level shortwave trough moved through, the snow shifted back south before an approaching system again brought the snows further north across the Buffalo metro area. Snowfall rates varied from one to as much as three inches of snow per hour. The greatest snow totals off Lake Erie fell across the Southern Tier where narrow but intense bands of snow brought localized amounts of over two feet of snow. Significant snows over one foot also fell across Grand Island and southern Niagara County. Much of the Greater Buffalo area had a large gradient in snow totals ranging from 3 inches to around a foot due to the transient nature of the band on Saturday morning.|Off Lake Ontario, lake snows organized into a narrow but intense band of snow over southern Jefferson County as winds aligned down the long axis of the lake. This band sagged south across central Oswego County where snowfall rates of up to 2 inches per hour were observed. The lake band briefly pushed south over the southern shore of Lake Ontario with heavier lake snows making for a messy morning commute in the Rochester metro area. The band then lifted north into Jefferson County with heavy snow for the Watertown area. Some of the highest snowfall rates of this event were observed across northern Jefferson County with three to four inches per hour falling. The greatest snow totals off Lake Ontario fell during two periods. During the first, six to as much as twenty-one inches were measured in central Oswego and southern Lewis Counties. During the second, six to sixteen inches were measured across northern Jefferson County.

A cold airmass over the warmer waters of Lakes Erie and Ontario produced lake effect snows off both lakes. |Off Lake Erie, a disorganized band of lake effect snow began across far southern Erie and Wyoming counties then shifted south, becoming better organized. Snowfall rates in excess of two inches an hour dropped several feet of snow across Northern Cayuga and Oswego Counties. Specific reports included 33 inches at Fulton, 25 inches at Fair Haven and Sterling, and 17 inches at Phoenix.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow produced 7 to 10 inches. The highest accumulation of 10 inches fell in Brewerton.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold westerly flow produced significant lake effect snowfall in portions of central New York.

Lake effect snows developed off both Lake Erie and Ontario in a typical westerly flow.  Snowfall rates of an inch an hour off Lake Erie and two inches an hour off Lake Ontario were reported. Diurnal effect diminished the lake snows somewhat during the day and dry air building in from the central Great Lakes brought an end to the snows by the late evening of the 21st. Specific snowfall reports off Lake Erie:  20 inches at Westfield, Springville and Franklinville; 19 inches at Perrysburg and 15 inches at Ripley. Snowfall reports off Lake Ontario:  36 inches at North Osceola; 26 inches at Constableville; 25 inches at Bennetts Bridge; and 21 inches at Hooker.

In the wake of a winter storm, a northwest flow of air allowed for very cold aloft to  move into the region.  As this cold air crossed over the water of Lake Ontario, a broken band of lake effect snow developed during the evening of Tuesday, March 19th. ||This snow moved across the Tughill Plateau and into the western Adirondacks from the evening of Tuesday, March 19th into the early morning hours of Wednesday, March 20th.  The band of snow continued through the day on Wednesday, March 20th, although the band became less intense and oscillated across the region at times.  The lake effect snow reorganized during the evening of the 20th into the early morning hours of Thursday, March 21st. ||The lake effect snow began to finally break up just prior to sunrise on Thursday, March 21st as the flow shifted due to an approaching upper level shortwave trough.  By that time, lake effect snows produced a storm total of up to a foot of new snow across portions of the Western Adirondacks (northern Herkimer County).

Snowfall reports off Lake Ontario:  36 inches at North Osceola; 26 inches at Constableville; 25 inches at Bennetts Bridge; and 21 inches at Hooker.

Lake effect snows developed off both Lake Erie and Ontario in a typical westerly flow.  Snowfall rates of an inch an hour off Lake Erie and two inches an hour off Lake Ontario were reported. Diurnal effect diminished the lake snows somewhat during the day and dry air building in from the central Great Lakes brought an end to the snows by the late evening of the 21st. Specific snowfall reports off Lake Erie:  20 inches at Westfield, Springville and Franklinville; 19 inches at Perrysburg and 15 inches at Ripley. Snowfall reports off Lake Ontario:  36 inches at North Osceola; 26 inches at Constableville; 25 inches at Bennetts Bridge; and 21 inches at Hooker.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow produced 11.3 inches at the Syracuse Airport.
